comment.author: 22915586@N03
comment._content: This is the front end of a C-47.  The woman has inserted the rivit and is controlling the rivit gun.  The man is holding a "T" bucking bar against the end of the rivit so it will flare and draw the aluminum sheets together.  Styaged, but nice.

comment.author: 39312862@N00
comment._content: The lighting is incredible. Really good stuff.

comment.author: 54459687@N00
comment._content: Great lighting to highlight just the subject closely.. But I recall from other shots of the era, that this was how it was done

comment.author: 21910531@N03
comment._content: I didn't know there was transparency film in 1942.  I agree with ChrisRudge and Eric in SF.  This is great lighting.  I had one flight in a C47.  Was this the one?

comment.author: 39312862@N00
comment._content: Kodachrome came out in 1935. There were earlier, larger format color reversal films prior to Kodachrome.

comment.author: 21910531@N03
comment._content: Thanks Eric in SF, I have some 40 year old transparently film that has lost some color.  It  is amazing that these have retained the color purity they have.

comment.author: 39312862@N00
comment._content: Kodachrome in particular among color reversal films is known for its color stability and longevity. E-6 usually is listed as having a maximum storage age of 50 years. Kodachrome is 200 years.

comment.author: 32085432@N02
comment._content: thank you so much for posting

comment._content: Thanks for identifying the plane model! For a similar photo, see www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2179068949
